Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, eyes glued to the clock. Only an hour left, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need you to hit your numbers this week.” I dialed another number, rehearsing my pitch, when I caught a glimpse of my stepbrother through the window. He was fiddling with his phone, heading straight for the busy street outside our house, not even glancing up at the traffic. My heart pounded. I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe—Mom had said so when we first moved in together. But if I left my desk now, I’d lose precious minutes, maybe miss my last chance to make those sales. The pressure from work and the responsibility at home crashed together inside me, leaving me frozen, headset in hand, torn between the ringing phone and the open window.
